It's not really disputed that the conflict began due to the government's overreaction against some anti-government graffiti, and then to its repeated violent overreactions against increasingly large protests until a fair portion of the population decided that peaceful protest was getting anywhere.

It's been complicated much more since then -- notably, the stakes are quite high for Iran and Hizbullah, and so could any consequences. It's much too late to prevent a catastrophe in Syria because it already is one (huge number of displaced persons, internally and externally, in addition to severe damage to civil society), and it's already having negative impact on Lebanon (related violence in Beirut and Tripoli; Tripoli quite recently had a car bomb, first one in years). It's already involved Turkey and Jordan (which are hosting refugees *and* FSA folks, with reports that the CIA has been doing some training in Jordan).

At present, we should probably be satisfied if we can reduce the likelihood of Lebanon exploding (so far, this seems plausible as it doesn't look like any major faction there is eager to restart the civil war, but smaller factions may not share that stance) and trying to stop the Syria from turning into an Iranian client state dependent upon Tehran for its very survival, and therefore beholden to its will.

"For a lot of people in the northern United States, this would mean forgoing all fruit during the winter months."

That is absolutely untrue. There are many varieties of apples and pears that actually improve with storage and can be even better than freshly picked right through to the following spring. There are early, mid-season, and late varieties of any fruit you care to grow or eat so that, for example, you can have raspberries or apples over many months. Dried fruit is excellent! Many Europeans and Americans knew these things in the days when people ate locally, and selected fruits for different uses--fresh, cider (hard and sweet), cooking, drying, preserves, etc., which is how we inherited hundreds and hundreds of named varieties of apples, for example.

Why has the sociology of economics gone so wrong?

Lack of falsification. Scientific theories can be falsified forcing most practitioners to change their views if they become at variance to observation. This doesn't seem to work well in social sciences, including economics. Whether social science attracts people who prefer not to have their theories falsified or there are other factors at work is an interesting question.
